channel.title: Timers & Stuff
channel.description: What are timers? I have been running a moparscape server for a few months and I'm pretty good at coding the small stuff but I really want to be a good coder but alot of people on here if I ask a question they'll call me a noob or something... It's just weird. :confused: Please help me!

item.title: Timers & Stuff

@Gh0stb4rr4g3 wrote:

WHAT are timers ? Timers can help you so they are HELPFULL ;o

Lol sorry didn’t saw it.

But they’ll help you at a few commands.

-gh0st

item.title: Timers & Stuff
item.dc:creator: @x_blitz_x x blitz x
item.description:
@x_blitz_x wrote:

[quote=“slomifier, post:7, topic:240447”]nlink, you mean set it to go off at a certain time and date? That’s a different mater then. I’ve never used it, but you can import a self updating time and date handler. I think it’s called GeorgianTime, so try:

import java.georgiantime

or

import java.system.georgiantime

and I’m pretty sure it uses the variables day, month and year, but don’t quote me on that. Then create a method that checks the current date against the target date, and activates whatever you want accordingly. Check at the top of your client.java and see if you have the time importer

This is all off of memory (which I lack) so, if a senior user sees this, maybe they can correct me.[/quote]

There is no such package(s).

java.util.Date

Has the compareTo(Date) Method.

Method: compareTo(Date anotherDate)

Returns:
integer.

Description:
Compares two Dates for ordering.

But then you could just use the Timer and TimerTask imports.

    int numberOfMillisecondsInTheFuture = 10000; // 10 sec in the future.
    Date timeToRun = new Date(System.currentTimeMillis()+numberOfMillisecondsInTheFuture);
    Timer timer = new Timer();
    
    timer.schedule(new TimerTask() {
            public void run() {
                // Task here ...
            }
        }, timeToRun);

Read full topic

item.title: Timers & Stuff
item.dc:creator: @slomifier slomifier
item.description:
@slomifier wrote:

nlink, you mean set it to go off at a certain time and date? That’s a different mater then. I’ve never used it, but you can import a self updating time and date handler. I think it’s called GeorgianTime, so try:

import java.georgiantime

or

import java.system.georgiantime

and I’m pretty sure it uses the variables day, month and year, but don’t quote me on that. Then create a method that checks the current date against the target date, and activates whatever you want accordingly. Check at the top of your client.java and see if you have the time importer

This is all off of memory (which I lack) so, if a senior user sees this, maybe they can correct me.

Read full topic

item.title: Timers & Stuff
item.dc:creator: @x_blitz_x x blitz x
item.description:
@x_blitz_x wrote:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timers:

A timer is a specialized type of clock. A timer can be used to control the sequence of an event or process. Whereas a stopwatch counts upwards from zero for measuring elapsed time, a timer counts down from a specified time interval, like an hourglass.

Read full topic

item.title: Timers & Stuff
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

  1. Int’s can’t handle decimals, only doubles, floats (i think)
  2. for an actual timer, you need to do some processor timers. if you look in server.java iirc, it has like “lastEntityUpdate” or something like that…

item.title: Timers & Stuff
item.dc:creator: @slomifier slomifier
item.description:
@slomifier wrote:

WHat do you mean what are timers. They are a variable that can count down or up, and triggers an event when a certain value is achieved. Pretty easy to do. I use the boolean process, some say not to. You can put this is in the public boolean (I’m tired, bare with me):

[code]
if (timer >= MIN AMMOUNT && timer <= MAX AMMOUNT){
timer += 0.5;
}
If (timer >= TRIGGER AMMOUNT){
WHAT HAPPENS WHEN TRIGGER IS ACHIEVED
}

[code]

Couple problems. I honestly cannot remember if integers can handle decimals. If they cannot, simple state the variable “timer” as a double.

And, like I said, people often frown upon using the public boolean. I don’t, but it can cause lag.

Hope it helps![/code][/code]

Read full topic
